label.text: Light Pollution
Scientific evidence indicates that artificial light at night has negative effects on many living organisms, including plants as well as animals.
The photo below shows artificial light on Earth. Light from the Sun is visible on the horizon.
Light Pollution

Scientists conducted experiments to study the effect of artificial night lighting on a grassland ecosystem. One of the experiments studied the impact of night lighting on the behaviour of insects, such as the ground beetle.

The scientists installed 10 LED lamps in an unmanaged grassland, as shown below. Pitfall traps, which trap ground insects, were placed under the lamps (light areas) and between the lamps (dark areas).

For one week, at the end of each night and the end of each day, the scientists counted the number of ground beetles that had fallen into the pitfall traps. The scientists released the trapped insects by scattering them randomly over the grassland.
pitfall trap

Light Pollution
At the end of the last century, cities were most often lit by high-pressure sodium lamps, which produce a yellow light.
In the 21st century, the LED (light-emitting diode) light is used more because it consumes less energy.

However, scientific studies show that LED light causes more disturbances to the biological cycles of living organisms than the high-pressure sodium lamps because the light is more like natural daylight.

Filters can be placed in front of lamps to block some wavelengths of light but allow other wavelengths of light to pass through. For example, a yellow filter will only allow yellow light to pass through it.
